questions.text: Arlt’s line is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Trachoma

Explanation:

Signs in Trachoma:

Signs of active trachoma

Signs of cicatricial trachoma

Conjunctival signs:

  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva: Look like sago-grains
  • Papillary enlargement: red, velvety

Conjunctival signs:

  • Scarring
    • It may be irregular, star-shaped, or linear
    • Linear scar in the sulcus subtarsalis is called Arlt’s line (Option C)
  • accumulation of dead epithelial cells and inspissated mucus in the glands of Henle
  • Pseudocyst
  • Xerosis
  • Symblepharon

Corneal signs:

  • Superficial keratitis on slit lamp and fluorescein
  • Herbert’s follicles
  • Progressive pannus/Trachomatous pannus: The upper part of the cornea is cloudy
  • Corneal ulcers are common at the advancing edge of the pannus
    • Shallow, little infiltrated
    • Cause lacrimation and photophobia

Corneal signs:

  • Regressive pannus or pannus siccus:
    • Receding infiltration
    • Vessels extend beyond the area of infiltration and haze
  • Herbert pits: oval or circular pitted scars formed after the healing of Herbert’s follicles in the limbal area
  • Vascularized and opaque cornea.
  • Corneal xerosis
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Total corneal pannus (blinding sequelae)

 

 

Lid signs:

  • Distortion of the lids
  • Tylosis : Thickening of the tarsal plate/lid margin
  • Trichiasis due to rubbing of lashes on the cornea
  • Trachomatous ptosis (sleepy appearance)
  • Entropion
  • Madarosis
  • Ankyloblepharon

Lacrimal apparatus sequelae:

  • Chronic dacryocystitis
  • Chronic dacryoadenitis

 

Images:

Active Trachoma

 

Follicles in upper palpebral conjunctiva

 

Trachomatous pannus

Progressive pannus

Cicatricial

Trachoma

​​​​​​

 

 

Regressive pannus

 

Conjunctival concretions

 

Trichiasis

Tylosis (thickening of tarsal border of eyelid)

Incorrect Options:

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (Option A) is characterized by intense itching, redness, watery discharge, and cobblestone appearance of upper palpebral conjunctiva.

Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis (Option B) is characterized by the formation of small nodules called as phlycten near limbus or ulcers on the cornea.

Pterygium (Option D) is conjunctival degeneration characterized by triangular fibrovascular subepithelial ingrowth of bulbar conjunctiva over the limbus.

questions.text: Which layer is accountable for preserving the moisture and clarity of the cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Endothelium

Explanation:

Layers of Cornea

Epithelium

(Option D ruled out)
  • The outermost layer comprises 5-6 layers of non-keratinized, stratified squamous epithelial cells.
  • Acts as a barrier, protecting the cornea and preventing tear fluid from entering the underlying stroma.
  • The basal cells at the limbus are stem cells responsible for regenerating the corneal epithelium.

Bowman’s Membrane
  • Located just beneath the epithelium, this acellular layer is 12 µm thick and composed of densely packed collagen fibrils.
  • It is a protective barrier to the stroma but cannot regenerate if damaged and heals by scarring.

Stroma

(Option C ruled out)
  • Making up about 90% of the cornea's thickness (approximately 0.5 mm thick), the stroma consists of collagen fibrils arranged in parallel layers.
  • These fibrils are embedded in a hydrated matrix of proteoglycans - Chondroitin and Keratan Sulphate (keratan sulphate maintains corneal transparency).

Pre-Descemet's Membrane (Dua's Layer)

  • This layer, discovered in 2013, is about 15 µm thick, acellular, and lies just above Descemet's membrane.
  • It is strong and resistant to air penetration.

Descemet's Membrane (Option A ruled out)
  • A robust basement membrane of the corneal endothelium is made of collagen and glycoproteins.
  • It is tense, but when torn, curls inwards on itself.
  • It can regenerate if damaged and is resistant to trauma and pathological processes.

Endothelium

(Option B)
  • The innermost layer consists of a single layer of flat, hexagonal cells.
  • These cells are crucial for maintaining corneal transparency by regulating fluid balance within the cornea through an active pump mechanism.

questions.text: What is the distinguishing characteristic of a fungal ulcer?

choices.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescein dye

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Satellite lesion

Explanation:

Keratomycosis

Clinical Features

  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering of the eye
  • Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision
  • Redness.

Examination Findings

  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry-looking with elevated, rolled-out margins.
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish appearance, possible with dematiaceous fungi.
  • Feathery Extensions: Delicate, finger-like projections into the surrounding stroma.
  • Sterile Immune Ring: Yellow line of demarcation where fungal antigen and host antibodies meet.
  • Satellite Lesions (Option D): Multiple small lesions around the main ulcer.
  • Hypopyon (Option A ruled out): Large, non-sterile, even with a small ulcer.
  • Endothelial Plaque: Located under the stromal lesion, made of fibrin and leucocytes.
  • Corneal Vascularization: Typically absent in pure fungal ulcers.
  • Perforation: Rare but possible.

Investigations

  • Corneal Scraping: Performed under topical anaesthesia for microbiological examination.
  • Wet KOH Mount: Reveals filamentous fungi (branched, septate hyphae) or non-filamentous yeast-like fungi (Candida).
  • Gram's & Giemsa Stains: To detect fungal hyphae and inflammatory cells.
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar medium is used for fungal culture.
  • PCR: Recommended for rapid identification of fungal pathogens.
  • Anterior Chamber Paracentesis: Considered if there is an intraocular extension.
  • Corneal Biopsy: Indicated for deep stromal abscess or when cultures are negative.
  • Confocal Microscopy: Used for identifying actual fungi within the cornea.

Incorrect Options: 

Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescein dye (Option B) is a characteristic finding of herpetic keratitis caused by the herpes simplex virus.

Ring abscess (Option C) is seen in Acanthamoeba keratitis commonly seen in patients using contact lens and using tap water to clean it.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman with a history of trauma to the left eye 5 days back now presented with complaints of complete loss of vision. Upon examination the following findings were seen. What should be the subsequent course of action to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Keratoplasty

Explanation:

  • The history of trauma to the eye and complete loss of vision and examination finding revealing congestion and corneal perforation is suggestive of uncontrolled keratitis commonly seen with bacterial keratitis. The choice of treatment for corneal perforation with uncontrolled infection penetrating is keratoplasty.

Penetrating Keratoplasty (PK):

  • It is a type of Allografting (Allo-Keratoplasty) which is the replacement of a patient’s diseased cornea with a healthy donor cornea.
  • Full-thickness grafting.

 

Indications for Penetrating Keratoplasty:

 

Optical
  • Corneal opacity
  • Bullous keratopathy
  • Corneal dystrophies
  • Advanced keratoconus

Therapeutic

To replace an inflamed cornea that does not respond to conventional therapy

Tectonic Graft

To restore the integrity of the eyeball, e.g., after corneal perforation (Option A) or in cases of significant corneal thinning.

Cosmetic

To improve the appearance of the eye

Complications: (ak142)

  • Early Complications:
    • Flat anterior chamber
    • Iris prolapse
    • Infection
    • Secondary glaucoma
    • Epithelial defects
    • Primary graft failure
  • Late Complications:
    • Graft rejection
    • Recurrence of disease
    • Astigmatism

Incorrect Options
 

Keratotomy (Option B) is used for correcting refractive error causing flattening of the cornea and reducing its focusing power.

LASIK (Option C) surgery is commonly used for keratomileusis, which is altering of the curvature of the cornea, done for refractive correction. .

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) (Option D) is a surgical procedure done for dacryocystitis.

questions.text: Which glycosaminoglycan is responsible for the transparency of the cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Keratan sulfate

Explanation:

  • Keratan sulfate and chondroitin sulfate are the major glycosaminoglycan present in the corneal stroma. They exist in the proteoglycan form and are responsible for maintaining the space between the regularly oriented layers of collagen fibrils in the stroma.

Locations of Various Mucopolysaccharides

Mucopolysaccharide

Primary Locations

Functions

Hyaluronic Acid (Option B)

Connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid, vitreous humor

Serves as a lubricant in joint cavities and contributes to the structure of connective tissues

Heparin (Option C)

Liver, lungs, spleen, monocytes

Acts as an anticoagulant by activating antithrombin III, which inactivates thrombin and other clotting factors

Chondroitin Sulfate

Cartilage, bone, tendons, cornea, skin

Provides structural support to connective tissues and contributes to their resilience and elasticity

Keratan Sulfate (Option A)

Cornea, cartilage

 

Dermatan Sulfate (Option D)

Skin, blood vessels, heart valves

Contributes to the structure of the skin, blood vessels, and heart valves

questions.text: A corneal wisp test was performed, and the corneal reflex was elicited. Which of the following nerves is responsible for the afferent limb of this reflex?
questions.solution:
The corneal reflex (blink reflex) is a protective response that involves both sensory (afferent) and motor (efferent) pathways:

  • Afferent limb (sensory input): Trigeminal nerve (CN V1 - Ophthalmic division)
    • The cornea is innervated by the nasociliary branch of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve.
    • A light touch to the cornea (e.g., with a cotton wisp) stimulates sensory fibers, sending signals to the trigeminal sensory nucleus in the brainstem.
  • Efferent limb (motor response): Facial nerve (CN VII)
    • The facial nerve (CN VII) innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, which causes eyelid closure in response to the stimulus.

 

Reflex

Afferent Nerve

Efferent Nerve

Accommodation

II (Optic nerve)

III (Oculomotor nerve)

Corneal

V₁ (Ophthalmic, nasociliary branch)

Bilateral VII (Facial nerve, temporal branch - orbicularis oculi)

Cough

X (Vagus nerve)

X (Vagus nerve, also phrenic and spinal nerves)

Gag

IX (Glossopharyngeal nerve)

X (Vagus nerve)

Jaw Jerk

V₃ (Mandibular branch, sensory from masseter)

V₃ (Mandibular branch, motor to masseter)

Lacrimation

V₁ (Ophthalmic branch) (loss of reflex does not preclude emotional tears)

VII (Facial nerve)

Pupillary

II (Optic nerve)

III (Oculomotor nerve)

 

Facial Nerve (CN VII) (Option A): The facial nerve is responsible for the efferent limb (motor response), not the afferent limb. It causes eyelid closure by contracting the orbicularis oculi muscle.

 

Oculomotor Nerve (CN III) (Option C): CN III controls extraocular muscles and the levator palpebrae superioris (eyelid elevation), but it does not mediate the corneal reflex.

 

Abducens Nerve (CN VI) (Option D): CN VI controls the lateral rectus muscle for eye abduction but is not involved in the corneal reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pterygium?

choices.text: Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Conjunctival invasion making a flap over cornea

Explanation:

Pterygium/Surfer’s eye

 

 

 

 

 

 

Definition

Pterygium is a triangular encroachment of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area.

  • Parts: Cap, head, neck, body
  • Degenerative process

 

Aetiology

  • Common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils
  • Ultraviolet light is a probable factor
  • Usually elderly persons

 

 

 

 

 

Pathology

Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma.

 

 

Pathogenesis

  • Degenerative subconjunctival proliferation
  • Granulation tissue proliferates as avascularized tissue encroaches on the cornea.
  • Destroys the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane

 

 

 

Symptoms

  • Frequently follows a pinguecula
  • Often bilateral
  • Usually on the nasal side
  • Impairment of vision due to:
    • Progression into the pupillary area of the cornea
    • Induced astigmatism by corneal flattening in the axis of pterygium
  • Progressive pterygium: thick and vascular
  • Regressive pterygium: thin, pale, and atrophic
  • Ceases to grow but never disappears
  • A probe can be passed under the lesion
  • Can present as inflammed pterygium

Signs

  • A probe cannot be passed under the lesion
  • Fusch’s spots/Islets of Vogt: small discrete whitish flecks made of pterygial epithelial cells seen in progressive pterygium and are also called the cap of the pterygium.
  • Stocker line: linear epithelial iron deposition, seen in regressive pterygium.

 

Management of pterygium:

 

 

 

Management

  • Best left alone

Medical treatment:

  • Tear substitutes for small regressive pterygium with dry eye
  • Topical steroids for associated inflammation
  • Protection from UV rays with sunglasses

Surgical excision for:

  • Progression of lesion towards the pupillary area causing excessive astigmatism and visual impairment
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Disfiguring
  • Diplopia

 

 

Procedures
  • Bare sclera technique:
    • The pterygium is excised from the cornea and conjunctiva, leaving a bare sclera
    • Associated with a high recurrence rate
  • Autoconjunctival graft
    • A piece of limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or the other eye or
    • An amniotic membrane graft is used to cover the bare sclera
    • Sutured at the limbus to cover the defect
  • Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty for deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia
  • Old methods (not used now):
    • McRaynold’s operation
    • Postoperative use of beta irradiations

 

Post-operative therapy and care
  • Prevent recurrence:
    • Mitomycin C 0.02% drops
    • Complications like scleral necrosis, cataracts, and iritis

questions.text: For which of the subsequent diseases is collagen cross-linking therapy utilized?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Keratoconus

Explanation:

Treatment of Keratoconus:

  • Spectacle Correction:
    • Effective in the early stages, but contact lenses are more beneficial.
    • Less effective in later stages due to irregular astigmatism.
  • Contact Lenses:
    • Rigid gas permeable lenses improve vision in early cases.
    • Specially designed scleral lenses (e.g., Rose-K) are useful in early to moderate cases.
  • Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking (CXL) (Option A) :
    • New treatment modality to slow disease progression.
    • Involves riboflavin (0.1%) eye drops and UVA radiation.
    • Riboflavin induces cross-linking of corneal collagen to stabilize the stroma and improve contact lens tolerance.
  • Keratoplasty :
    • Recommended if disease progresses or in cases of acute hydrops (Descemet's membrane tear).
    • Reserved for more advanced diseases or when other treatments fail.
    • Penetrating keratoplasty is common, but Deep Anterior Lamellar Keratoplasty (DALK) is preferred if Descemet's membrane and endothelium are intact, reducing rejection risk.
  • Intracorneal Ring Segments (INTACS) :
    • Effective in early to moderate cases by flattening the cornea.
    • Less effective in halting progression.

Incorrect Options:

Corneal ulcer (Option B) are treated with antibiotics, antivirals, or antifungals, depending on the cause.

Band keratopathy (Option C) involves calcium deposition in the superficial cornea and is treated with chelation therapy or surgical interventions like superficial keratectomy.

Uveitis (Option B) is inflammation of the uveal tract and is typically managed with corticosteroids, immunosuppressive agents, or biologics.

questions.text: What's the main risk for a 37-year-old man with blurred vision and severe pain in his right eye? He revealed that recently, he went swimming in a pond. During examination, a ring-like lesion was found, as seen in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Soft Contact lenses:

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of blurred vision, severe pain after swimming in a pond with ring like lesion on examination is suggestive of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis:

It is caused by Acanthamoeba, a free-living amoeba found in water, causes severe corneal infections

Risk Factors:

  1. Contact Lens Use (Primary Risk Factor)
  2. Exposure to Contaminated Water
  3. Trauma
  4. Immunosuppression
  5. Use of Homemade Saline Solutions.
  6. Poor Lens Storage Conditions

Examination Findings in Acanthamoeba Keratitis:

Symptoms:

  • Blurred Vision: Common in corneal conditions due to the disruption of the cornea's transparent surface.
  • Discomfort: Significant discomfort in the affected eye.
  • Severe Pain: Pain is often out of proportion to clinical signs, a key clinical clue.

Signs:

Early Disease:

  • Irregular and Greyish Epithelium: Early sign indicating amoebic invasion.
  • Pseudodendrites: Lesions resembling herpetic keratitis
  • Limbitis and Stromal Infiltrates: Inflammation at the corneal-scleral junction with diffuse or focal infiltrates in the anterior stroma.
  • Perineural Infiltrates (Radial Keratoneuritis): Hallmark sign, radial streaks extending towards the cornea's centre, pathognomonic for Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Advanced Disease:

  • Ring Abscess: Characteristic of advanced infection, where infiltrates form a ring-shaped abscess.
  • Stromal Opacification and Vascularisation: Corneal opacity and new blood vessel growth, leading to significant vision impairment.
  • Corneal Melting: Serious complication where corneal tissue breaks down, often at the infiltrate edges.
  • Scleritis: Reactive inflammation of the sclera, not a direct infection extension.

Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a female patient, aged 65, who has a history of chickenpox and presents at the clinic with the following findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Herpes zoster ophthalmicus

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of a patient with history of chickenpox and cutaneous lesions seen along the course of trigeminal nerve is suggestive of Herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (HZO)

  • Affects the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Anterior uveitis occurs in 40-50% of cases, usually within 2 weeks of skin rash onset.
  • Symptoms: mild iritis, vesicular rash on the nose, small KPs, mild aqueous flare, possible hemorrhagic hypopyon.
  • Complications: iris atrophy, secondary glaucoma, complicated cataracts.

Incorrect Options:

Chicken pox exacerbation (Option A), caused by the varicella-zoster virus, usually occurs in children and presents with a generalized vesicular rash. Reactivation of the virus in adults leads to herpes zoster rather than an exacerbation of chickenpox.

Drug allergy to acyclovir (Option B), a common antiviral medication used to treat herpes zoster, would typically present with skin rashes, itching, or swelling after drug exposure.

Herpes zoster oticus (Option D) (Ramsay Hunt syndrome) involves the facial nerve and affects the ear, causing pain, vesicular rash in the ear canal, and facial paralysis. It does not primarily affect the eye or lead to keratitis.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has a previous history of wearing contact lenses, and is currently experiencing pain, redness, and the presence of pus coming from his right eye? During examination, a greyish-white ulcer in the shape of a snake was observed on the lower portion of the cornea. Additionally, a hypopyon measuring 4 mm was found in the anterior chamber, along with a moderate flare reaction.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bacterial corneal ulcer

Explanation:

  • Bacterial corneal ulcers present with redness, pain, and discharge. Signs include a greyish-white serpiginous ulcer seen over the lower third of the cornea, indicative of the bacteria

Aetiology of Purulent Corneal Ulcer:

  • Corneal Epithelial Damage:

    • Due to Corneal abrasion, epithelial drying (xerosis, exposure keratitis), necrosis (keratomalacia), desquamation (bullous keratopathy), and trophic changes (neuroparalytic keratitis).

  • Pathogens Invading Intact Epithelium:

    • Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus aegyptius, Listeria species.

  • Sources of Infection:

    • Exogenous Sources: Conjunctival sac, lacrimal sac (dacryocystitis), infected foreign bodies, vegetative material, waterborne or airborne infections.

  • Common Bacteria Associated with Corneal Ulceration:

    • General: Staphylococci, Pseudomonas, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Enterobacteriaceae, Neisseria.

    • In Contact Lens Wearers: Pseudomonas is the most common cause. Acanthamoeba is another differential in contact lens misuse.

  • All causative organisms:

    • Gram-positive Cocci: Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae.

    • Gram-negative Cocci: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Neisseria meningitidis.

    • Gram-positive Bacilli: Corynebacterium diphtheriae, C. xerosis, Bacillus cereus, Propionibacterium acne, Listeria, Clostridium.

    • Gram-negative Bacilli: Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacteriaceae (Klebsiella, Proteus, E. coli, Serratia), Moraxella lacunata, Haemophilus influenzae.

    • Gram-positive Filamentous Bacteria: Actinomyces, Nocardia.

    • Mycobacteria: Non-tuberculous mycobacteria, M. tuberculosis.

Clinical Features of Bacterial Corneal Ulcers:

Symptoms:

  • Pain and foreign body sensation.

  • Watery eye (reflex hyper lacrimation).

  • Photophobia (light intolerance).

  • Blurred vision.

  • Redness of the eye.

Signs:

  • Lid swelling.

  • Blepharospasm (lid twitching).

  • Conjunctival chemosis and hyperemia.

  • Corneal ulcer characteristics:

    • Early stage: Epithelial defect with greyish-white infiltrate.

    • Established: Yellowish-white ulcer, swollen margins, necrotic floor, stromal oedema.

  • Specific bacterial features:

    • Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pneumoniae: Oval, yellowish-white ulcer surrounded by clear cornea.

    • Pseudomonas species: Irregular ulcer with greenish exudate, rapid spread, often with hypopyon.

    • Enterobacteriaceae: Shallow ulcer with greyish-white suppuration, ring-shaped infiltrate.

  • The anterior chamber may contain pus (Hypopyon).

  • Muddy iris colour.

  • Small pupil due to iritis.

  • Possible raised intraocular pressure (inflammatory glaucoma).

Incorrect Options

Viral corneal ulcer (Option A) It is caused due to low immunity. A red, watery, and bloodshot eye is a prominent feature. There is severe eye pain and pus or other eye discharge. This can lead to vision loss and blindness.

Fungal corneal ulcer (Option C) Trauma is one of the causes of Fungal corneal ulcer. There is less pain and Hypopyon if present is thick and immobile.

Parasitic corneal ulcer (Option D) Is characterized by disproportionately severe pain and is caused by either contact lens wear or exposure to contaminated water.

questions.text: What is the main underlying factor responsible for regular astigmatism when studying the optics of a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Abnormal curvature of the cornea

Explanation:

  • The primary cause of regular astigmatism is an abnormal curvature of the cornea, which results in different refractive powers along different meridians of the eye. This irregularity in corneal shape prevents light rays from focusing on a single point on the retina, causing blurred or distorted vision.
  • Astigmatism: A refractive error where different meridia of the eye have different refractive errors. Divided into 2 types: Regular and irregular
  • I. Regular Astigmatism: When refraction error changes uniformly from one meridian to the other. ( 2 principle meridians present)

Type

Description

With-the-Rule (WTR)

The vertical meridian has greater curvature than the horizontal meridian.

Against-the-Rule (ATR)

The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian.

Oblique Astigmatism

Principal meridians are at oblique angles (e.g., 45° and 135°), still perpendicular to each other.

Bi-oblique Astigmatism

Principal meridians are not perpendicular to each other (e.g., 30° and 100°).

Regular Astigmatism Based on Focal Lines:

Type

Description

Simple Astigmatism

One meridian focuses on the retina; the other focuses in front (simple myopic) or behind (simple hypermetropic).

Compound Astigmatism

Both meridians focus light either in front (compound myopic) or behind (compound hypermetropic) the retina.

Mixed Astigmatism

One meridian focuses in front of the retina (myopic), and the other behind (hypermetropic).

II. Irregular Astigmatism Involves multiple, changing meridians of refractive power, making it geometrically complex.Usually due to Corneal scars.

Excessive eye rubbing (Option B) can irritate the eyes and potentially lead to infections like keratoconjunctivitis.

Prolonged exposure to bright light (Option C) can cause eye strain and discomfort.

Vitamin A deficiency (Option D) can lead to xerophthalmia characterized by night blindness and dryness of the eyes.

questions.text: What is the screening test that is most sensitive for detecting vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D. 

Night blindness is a symptom commonly associated with vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the proper functioning of the retina and the synthesis of rhodopsin, a pigment necessary for vision in low light conditions. When vitamin A levels are insufficient, the retina's ability to adapt to darkness is compromised, resulting in night blindness.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A. Serum retinal <10 μg/deciliter: While measuring serum retinol levels is a reliable test for assessing vitamin A deficiency, it is not the most sensitive screening test. Night blindness can occur even before serum retinol levels drop significantly, making it a more sensitive indicator in early stages of deficiency.

Option B. Beta carotene <50 μg/deciliter: Beta carotene is a precursor of vitamin A, and its levels can be used as an indicator of vitamin A status. However, it is not the most specific or sensitive test for vitamin A deficiency compared to night blindness.

Option C. Bitot spots: Bitot spots are visible signs of vitamin A deficiency, characterized by foamy, white patches on the conjunctiva. However, they are not commonly used as a screening test. Night blindness is a more indicative symptom in the context of vitamin A deficiency screening.

questions.text: Arlt’s line is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Trachoma:

  • Arlt's line is a finding seen in trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. It is a horizontal white line of inflammatory exudate at the upper tarsal conjunctiva, associated with scarring in the advanced stages of trachoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vernal keratoconjunctivitis: Arlt's line is not typically associated with vernal keratoconjunctivitis, which is characterized by papillary hypertrophy and a gelatinous limbal infiltrate.

Option B - Phlyctenular conjunctivitis: Arlt's line is not commonly seen in phlyctenular conjunctivitis. This condition is characterized by small nodules on the conjunctiva.

Option C - Ophthalmia neonatorum: Arlt's line is not typically associated with ophthalmia neonatorum, which refers to conjunctivitis occurring in the first month of life.

questions.text: In keratoplasty, the commonly used corneal storage medium and suture material are:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A)MK medium and 10-0 nylon

Explanation:

MK medium and 10-0 nylon (Option A): While MK medium is less common now for long-term storage, 10-0 nylon is definitively the most commonly used suture material. This makes the suture part of this answer very strong.

Moist chamber and Vicryl (Option B ruled out): Neither of these is commonly used for corneal grafts.

Optisol-GS and silk (Option C ruled out): Optisol-GS is the leading modern storage medium, but silk is not the commonly used suture for corneal grafts.

Eusol-C and 6-0 prolene (Option D ruled out): Eusol-C is a valid medium, but 6-0 prolene is too thick for corneal suturing.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless ulcer in the eye. On examination, a long, branching ulcer with desquamated epithelium is seen on the cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Neurotrophic ulcer

Explanation:

  • A painless corneal ulcer indicates reduced or absent corneal sensation.
  • The finding of a long, branching ulcer with desquamated epithelium but without the typical raised edges and terminal bulbs of herpes simplex keratitis suggests a neurotrophic ulcer.
  • Neurotrophic keratopathy results from damage to trigeminal nerve sensory supply, leading to impaired healing and epithelial breakdown, producing branching epithelial defects.

Neurotrophic Ulcer:

  1. Painless despite corneal epithelial defect.
  2. Decreased corneal sensation and epithelial desquamation.
  3. Often branching/irregular ulcer margins.
  4. Causes: herpes simplex/zoster, trigeminal nerve damage (tumor, surgery), diabetes, chronic topical medication toxicity.
  5. May follow procedures like Gasserian ganglion removal or blockage, often used in treating trigeminal neuralgia.
  6. Poor healing tendency due to loss of corneal reflex and trophic support.

Incorrect Options:

  • Fungal ulcer (Option A): Usually follows trauma with vegetative matter; presents with pain, feathery margins, satellite lesions, and hypopyon; not typically painless and branching like in neurotrophic ulcer.
  • Dendritic ulcer (Option B): Caused by herpes simplex virus; branching ulcer with terminal bulbs that stain with fluorescein; usually painful (unless corneal sensation is already lost).
  • Bacterial corneal ulcer (Option C): Acute, painful, purulent ulcer with stromal infiltration and hypopyon; rapid progression; not painless and not typically branching.

questions.text: A girl, after returning from a picnic, complains of pain in her eyes. She had not maintained proper hygiene of her contact lenses. What would be the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acanthamoeba

Explanation:

  • Improper contact lens hygiene, especially with exposure to contaminated water (picnic scenario, possible swimming), is a major risk factor for Acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • Acanthamoeba is a free-living protozoan found in water, soil, and air; it can adhere to contact lenses and invade the corneal epithelium, causing severe pain (often disproportionate to clinical signs), redness, tearing, and photophobia.
  • Classic sign: ring-shaped stromal infiltrate in advanced cases.

Acanthamoeba keratitis:

  1. Severe pain out of proportion to clinical findings.
  2. History of contact lens wear, especially poor hygiene or water exposure.
  3. Resistant to routine antibacterial therapy; requires specific anti-amoebic agents (e.g., polyhexamethylene biguanide, chlorhexidine).
  4. Delayed diagnosis can lead to corneal perforation and vision loss.

Examination Findings in Acanthamoeba Keratitis:

Symptoms:

  • Blurred Vision: Common in corneal conditions due to the disruption of the cornea's transparent surface.
  • Discomfort: Significant discomfort in the affected eye.
  • Severe Pain: Pain is often out of proportion to clinical signs, a key clinical clue.

Signs:

Early Disease:

  • Irregular and Greyish Epithelium: Early sign indicating amoebic invasion.
  • Pseudodendrites: Lesions resembling herpetic keratitis
  • Limbitis and Stromal Infiltrates: Inflammation at the corneal-scleral junction with diffuse or focal infiltrates in the anterior stroma.
  • Perineural Infiltrates (Radial Keratoneuritis): Hallmark sign, radial streaks extending towards the cornea's centre, pathognomonic for Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Advanced Disease:

  • Ring Abscess: Characteristic of advanced infection, where infiltrates form a ring-shaped abscess.
  • Stromal Opacification and Vascularisation: Corneal opacity and new blood vessel growth, leading to significant vision impairment.
  • Corneal Melting: Serious complication where corneal tissue breaks down, often at the infiltrate edges.
  • Scleritis: Reactive inflammation of the sclera, not a direct infection extension.

Investigations and Treatment of Acanthamoeba Keratitis:

Investigations:

  • Corneal Scraping:
    • The primary method for obtaining tissue for examination.
    • Scrape the margins and base of the lesion after applying a non-preserved topical anaesthetic.
  • Staining:
    • PAS (Periodic acid–Schiff) and Calcofluor white: Highly effective for visualizing Acanthamoeba cysts.
    • Gram and Giemsa stains: Less sensitive but can also demonstrate cysts.
  • Culture: Definitive diagnosis by culturing on non-nutrient agar with dead E. coli.
  • Additional Investigations:
    • Immunohistochemistry: Uses antibodies to detect specific Acanthamoeba antigens.
    • PCR: Useful for detecting Acanthamoeba DNA.
    • In Vivo Confocal Microscopy: Provides detailed images of Acanthamoeba cysts within the cornea.
  • Corneal Biopsy:
    • Considered if other diagnostic methods are inconclusive.

Treatment Modalities:

  • Debridement: Removal of infected epithelium to enhance topical medication penetration.
  • Topical Amoebicides:
    • PHMB (polyhexamethylene biguanide) 0.02% and Chlorhexidine 0.02%: Effective against both trophozoites and cysts.
    • Hexamidine: More effective than Propamidine (Brolene).
  • Topical Steroids:
    • Considered for persistent inflammation after two weeks of anti-amoebic treatment.
    • Caution against use if corneal thinning is present.
  • Pain Management: Oral NSAIDs are recommended for pain relief.
  • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Required for cases resistant to medical therapy or when corneal perforation occurs.

Incorrect Options:

Plasmodium (Option B): Causes malaria; does not cause keratitis or infection related to contact lenses.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option C): Most common bacterial cause of contact lens–related keratitis; produces rapid corneal ulceration, but here the focus is on protozoal infection linked to contaminated water exposure.

Herpes simplex virus (Option D): Causes dendritic keratitis; unrelated to contact lens hygiene and not typically triggered by recent outdoor water exposure.

questions.text: Which condition is treated using an Intacs ring, as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Keratoconus.

  • In the above image, the device implanted is an Intacs corneal ring segment, which is used to flatten and reshape the cornea in patients with keratoconus. This helps improve vision by reducing corneal irregularities and correcting refractive error. The transparent ring segments are inserted into the corneal stroma to provide structural support and reduce cone steepness.
  • Keratoconus is a progressive, non-inflammatory disorder of the cornea characterized by thinning and conical protrusion.

Symptoms: Progressive blurring, ghost images, glare, frequent change in glasses prescription.


Management options:

  • Early stage: Spectacles or rigid gas permeable contact lenses
  • Intermediate stage: Intacs corneal ring segments to reshape the cornea and delay corneal transplantation
  • Advanced stage: Corneal transplantation (DALK or PKP)

Intacs: Made of PMMA, placed in mid-peripheral corneal stroma; they reduce myopia and irregular astigmatism, improving best corrected visual acuity.

Cataract (Option B): Lens opacity; treated with lens extraction + IOL, unrelated to corneal rings.

Corneal ulcer (Option C): Infective/inflammatory; managed medically, not with implants.

Glaucoma (Option D): Optic nerve damage from high IOP; managed with drugs, laser, or filtering surgery.

questions.text: A patient presents with guttate lesions in one eye and bullous keratopathy in the other eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy

  • The patient has guttate lesions in one eye and bullous keratopathy in the other. Guttate lesions indicate endothelial cell loss, while bullous keratopathy results from corneal edema due to endothelial dysfunction. These are classical features of Fuchs’ endothelial dystrophy.
  • Fuchs’ endothelial dystrophy is a bilateral, progressive corneal endothelial disorder.
  • Early sign: Guttae (drop-like excrescences on Descemet membrane) seen on slit lamp.
  • Late stage: Stromal edema → epithelial edema → bullae formation (bullous keratopathy).

Symptoms: Gradual, painless decrease in vision; glare; haloes; worse in the morning due to overnight edema.

Treatment:

  • Early: Hypertonic saline drops, hair dryer to reduce morning edema
  • Advanced: Keratoplasty (DSEK, DMEK, or PK)

Interstitial keratitis (Option B) – Chronic stromal inflammation, usually post-infectious (e.g., syphilis, HSV); presents with stromal haze and vascularization, not guttate lesions or bullous keratopathy.

Viral corneal ulcer (Option C) – Painful red eye with epithelial defect and stromal infiltrate; acute onset, not a chronic, painless, bilateral process.

Keratoconjunctivitis (Option D) – Inflammatory condition involving cornea and conjunctiva; presents with redness, pain, photophobia, discharge; not consistent with long-standing endothelial degeneration.

questions.text: In the image provided, which refractive error is observed in the depicted condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Myopia and astigmatism

Explanation:

  • The image given above is that of Munson’s sign which is the V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze seen in Keratoconus. The refractive error seen in keratoconus is myopia and irregular astigmatism leading to defective vision.

Keratoconus:

Description
  • Progressive, non-inflammatory bilateral ectatic corneal condition affecting the axial part.

Pathology
  • Involves progressive thinning and ectasia of the cornea due to defective synthesis of mucopolysaccharides and collagen.

Clinical Features
  • Defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism (uncorrectable by glasses) (Option B)
  • Blurred and distorted vision, glare, and halos around lights
  • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation
  • Visual loss primarily from irregular astigmatism and myopia, secondary loss from corneal scarring

Examination Findings
  • Distorted Window Reflex: Visual irregularity on corneal reflection.
  • Placido Disc Irregularity: Irregular circles.
  • Slit-Lamp Examination:
    • Thinning and ectasia of the central cornea.
    • Opacity at the apex, Fleischer Ring (brownish ring around the cone due to haemosiderin in the epithelium).
    • Folds in Descemet's and Bowman's membranes.
  • Vogt Striae: Fine, parallel striae at the apex, disappearing with external pressure.
  • Oil Droplet Reflex: Annular dark shadow separating central and peripheral cornea in distant direct ophthalmoscopy.
  • Retinoscopy: Yawning reflex (scissor reflex) with high oblique/irregular astigmatism.
  • Ophthalmoscope Findings: Irregular astigmatism and progressive myopia, poorly corrected by glasses in later stages.
  • Munson's Sign: Localized bulging of the lower lid when looking down (seen in late stages).
  • Keratometer Findings: Malformed, malaligned, and malfocused mires.
  • Corneal Topography: Sensitive method for early detection, shows corneal surface shape.

Management

Spectacle Correction:

  • Effective in the early stages, but contact lenses are more beneficial.
  • Less effective in later stages due to irregular astigmatism.

Contact Lenses:

  • Rigid gas permeable lenses improve vision in early cases.
  • Specially designed scleral lenses (e.g., Rose-K) are useful in early to moderate cases.

Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking (CXL):

  • New treatment modality to slow disease progression.
  • Involves Riboflavin (0.1%) eye drops and UVA radiation.
  • Riboflavin induces cross-linking of corneal collagen to stabilize the stroma and improve contact lens tolerance.

Keratoplasty :

  • Recommended if disease progresses or in cases of acute hydrops (Descemet's membrane tear).
  • Reserved for more advanced diseases or when other treatments fail.
  • Penetrating keratoplasty is common, but Deep Anterior Lamellar Keratoplasty (DALK) is preferred if Descemet's membrane and endothelium are intact, reducing rejection risk.

Intracorneal Ring Segments (INTACS) :

  • Effective in early to moderate cases by flattening the cornea.
  • Less effective in halting progression.

questions.text: A patient sustained blunt trauma to the eye 6 months ago and now presents with blurring of vision. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Iridodialysis is detachment of iris from its root at the ciliary body. It results in D shaped pupil and a lack biconvex area seen at the periphery.

Blunt trauma (also known as non-penetrating or blunt force trauma)

  • Cause: A strong impact, a fall, or a physical assault with a blunt object, is most commonly the result of sports injuries and assaults.
  • Features:
    • Conjunctiva: Subconjunctival hemorrhage

    • Cornea: Abrasions, corneal edema, Descemet's membrane tears.
    • Hyphaema: Blood in the anterior chamber leading to corneal staining.
    • Iris: Iridodialysis (dehiscence of the iris from the ciliary body at its root), iris sphincter tear,
    • Ciliary body: Ciliary body tear leading to angle recession.
    • Lens:
      • Vossious Ring (in the shape of the pupil) (Option C)

      • Rosette-Shaped Cataract (flower-shaped opacity), subluxation of lens.

        • Globe rupture (caused by severe blunt trauma, indicated by iris prolapse)
        • Vitreous haemorrhage: Pigment cells (‘tobacco dust’) can be seen floating in the anterior vitreous.
        • Choroidal rupture
        • Retina: Commotio Retinae (also known as Berlin's edema), retinal dialysis (disinsertion from ora serrata), giant retinal Tear (horseshoe shaped), macular hole.

 

 

        • Injury to optic nerve
        • Traumatic neuropathy with chorioretinal scarring (decreased visual acuity, visual field defect, afferent pupillary defect, color, and brightness).


 

Ankyloblepharon (Option B): This refers to the abnormal fusion of the eyelids, typically a congenital issue or sometimes a result of trauma leading to scarring of the eyelids.

 

Cycloiriditis (Option D): This is inflammation of the ciliary body and iris. While trauma can trigger this, it usually presents with pain, redness, and photophobia (sensitivity to light) in addition to blurred vision.

questions.text: A patient presents with eyelid crusting and a thready sensation between the cornea and lids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chronic Blepharitis is an inflammation of the eyelid margins that can cause symptoms such as eyelid crusting and a thready sensation between the cornea and eyelids, often due to the accumulation of secretions along the lash line. The eyelids may feel gritty or have a foreign body sensation.


 

Bacterial blepharitis:

Definition

Chronic infection of the anterior part of the lid margin

Synonyms

  • Chronic anterior blepharitis
  • Staphylococcal blepharitis

Causative Organisms
  • Most commonly Staphylococci (coagulase positive)
  • Rarely Streptococci, Propionibacterium acnes, and Moraxella

Clinical Features
  • Chronic irritation
  • Itching
  • Mild lacrimation
  • Gluing of cilia
  • Mild photophobia
  • Yellow crusts at the root of cilia
  • Small ulcers that bleed easily when crusts are removed
  • Red, thickened lid margins with dilated blood vessels
  • Mild papillary conjunctivitis and conjunctival hyperemia

Treatment
  • Lid Hygiene:
    • Warm compresses
    • Cotton buds dipped in dilute baby shampoo or 3% sodium bicarbonate solution
    • Avoid touching
  • Antibiotics
  • Topical Steroids
  • Ocular Lubricants

 

Dry Eye Syndrome (Option B): While dry eyes can cause a foreign body sensation, it typically does not cause eyelid crusting. Dry eye symptoms are more related to discomfort from insufficient tear production, but the crusting is not a hallmark feature.

 

Meibomian Gland Dysfunction (Option C): This condition can lead to dry eyes and eyelid discomfort due to insufficient oil production, but it doesn’t usually cause eyelid crusting in the way that blepharitis does.

 

Conjunctivitis (Option D): Conjunctivitis (inflammation of the conjunctiva) causes symptoms such as redness, discharge, and itching

questions.text: A patient presents with redness, extreme eye pain, and diminished vision. The patient frequently wears contact lenses. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Acanthamoeba:

  • Acanthamoeba is most likely responsible for this patient's condition. Acanthamoeba keratitis is associated with improper use of contact lenses, and the patients exhibit extreme pain due to perineural invasion.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not responsible for causing this patient’s condition, as explained above.

questions.text: Shield ulcer is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Atopic keratoconjunctivitis

Explanation:

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis or Spring catarrh

It is a recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis that tends to occur with the onset of warm weather. It primarily affects young children and adolescents, particularly boys.

Course

The condition typically starts in childhood and may resolve on its own over 5–10 years.

Symptoms

Burning, Itching, Photophobia (sensitivity to light), and lacrimation (excessive tearing).

Signs
  • Palpebral Form: Hypertrophied palpebral conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance; bluish-white color; dense fibrous tissue with thickened epithelium.
  • Limbal or Bulbar Form: Opacification at the limbus, gelatinous thickening, and Horner–Trantas dots
  • Pseudogerontoxon/cupid’s bow (which resembles arcus senilis) is a grayish-white ring at the limbus seen in severe limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).
  • Shield ulcers are a significant complication of VKC, particularly in severe cases. These microerosions typically form on the upper third of the cornea.
  • Mixed form: Exhibits characteristics of both the tarsal (palpebral) and limbal subtypes, typically presenting in only one eye.

Maxwell Lyon's sign is a pseudomembrane formed due to excessive mucus deposition on the papilla resulting in cobblestone papillae.

Histology

In the palpebral form, hypertrophied papillae are observed, rich in eosinophils and other inflammatory cells.

Treatment
  • Topical therapy:
    • Antihistamines - Levocabastine & emedastine
    • Mast cell stabilizers - Sodium cromoglicate
    • Mild steroids - Fluorometholone and loteprednol etabonate,
    • Acetylcysteine can control excess mucus.
  • Local therapy: Subtarsal steroid injections and cryotherapy for severe cases.
  • Surgical treatment: Excision of giant papillae and treatment of shield ulcers with debridement and amniotic membrane or bandage contact lens.
  • Cold compresses and tinted glasses for comfort.
  • Avoid eye rubbing

Phlyctenular conjunctivitis (Option B):

  • Allergy caused by endogenous antigens → Staph. aureus and TB infection
  • It presents with watering and itching in the eyes
  • O/E: nodule of phlycten near the limbus and conjunctival congestion

Atopic keratoconjunctivitis (Option C):

  • Common in temperate regions and winters
  • Dennie-morgan folds present
  • Presence of Madarosis and Hertoghe’s sign

Autoimmune Conditions (Option D):

  • Not typically associated with Shield Ulcer: Various autoimmune diseases can affect the eyes, such as rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and Sjögren's syndrome, leading to conditions like dry eye, scleritis, and uveitis. However, shield ulcers are not commonly seen as a direct manifestation of these autoimmune conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is associated with the beaten bronze appearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endothelial Layer

Explanation:

Fuchs Endothelial Corneal Dystrophy is strongly associated with the "beaten-metal" appearance on Descemet's membrane. It is a common type of endothelial dystrophy (Option A), particularly affecting older adults.

Option B,C and D are not involved Fusch’s endothelial dystrophy

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient, who works in an iron factory, presents to the clinic with complaints of visual disturbances. He reports that his vision has been gradually worsening and he has noticed a change in the color perception. On examination, the ophthalmologist observes the presence of iron deposits in the eye. What is the most likely ocular condition responsible for the iron deposits in the eye and the patient's visual disturbances?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Siderosis bulbi

  • This is the correct answer. Siderosis bulbi refers to the condition in which iron particles, usually from a previous trauma, are deposited in the eye's intraocular tissues leading to visual disturbances and discoloration. In this case, the patient's line of work in an iron factory could have exposed him to iron particles.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hemochromatosis: This is a genetic disorder that leads to excessive iron absorption from the diet. It affects various organs in the body, including the liver, heart, and pancreas. While it can cause a number of health problems, it is not typically associated with iron deposits in the eye or the visual disturbances described by the patient.

Option C - Retinitis pigmentosa: This is a group of rare, genetic disorders that involve a breakdown and loss of cells in the retina—which is the light sensitive tissue that lines the back of the eye. It is not typically associated with iron deposits in the eye.

Option D - Age-related macular degeneration: This is a common eye condition among people over 50. It causes blurred or reduced central vision, due to thinning of the macula, the part of the retina responsible for clear vision in your direct line of sight. It is not associated with iron deposits in the eye.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of eye trauma with vegetative material .He complains of severe eye pain, redness, tearing, and photophobia. Microscopic examination of the corneal scraping reveals septate hyphae at an acute angle. What is the most likely causative agent responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fungal Corneal Ulcer 

  • Fungal corneal ulcers are typically caused by filamentous fungi, and they present with symptoms such as severe eye pain, redness, tearing, and photophobia. Microscopic examination of corneal scrapings often reveals septate hyphae at an acute angle. This presentation is consistent with the information provided in the question.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bacterial Corneal Ulcer: Bacterial corneal ulcers can also cause similar symptoms, including eye pain, redness, and tearing. However, bacterial ulcers are usually associated with a purulent discharge and the appearance of neutrophils on microscopic examination of corneal scrapings.

Option C - Viral Corneal Ulcer: Viral corneal ulcers, such as those caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV), typically present with a dendritic ulcer pattern on the cornea. They may cause symptoms like eye pain and photophobia, but they usually lack the septate hyphae seen in fungal infections.

Option D - Acanthamoeba Corneal Ulcer: Acanthamoeba corneal ulcers are caused by a protozoan parasite. They often occur in contact lens wearers or individuals exposed to contaminated water. These ulcers can cause eye pain, redness, and photophobia, but they are not characterized by septate hyphae

questions.text: Which of the following combinations corresponds to the image given below?

choices.text: Cobalt blue- Tryptan blue - Corneal ulcer
Cobalt green- Rose bengal stain- Corneal ulcer
Cobalt blue- Fluorescein stain- Corneal ulcer
Cobalt blue- Lissamine green- Corneal ulcer

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cobalt blue- Fluorescein stain- Corneal ulcer

Explanation:

The combination of cobalt blue light and fluorescein stain is the gold standard for evaluating corneal ulcers, making Option C the correct answer. This setup allows for optimal visualization of corneal defects and provides clear diagnostic information.

 

Fluorescein sodium

  • Fluorescein penetrates poorly into the lipid layer of the corneal epithelium, and therefore, it does not stain normal cornea. Although fluorescein is a very effective stain for the diseased cornea, it is more difficult to detect fluorescein staining of the conjunctiva because of the poor scleral contrast. Fluorescein absorbs light in the blue spectrum (490 nm) and emits yellow-green light of a higher wavelength (530 nm), therefore staining can be more readily viewed if a cobalt blue or yellow (blue-free) filter is used. This combination is particularly useful for detecting corneal defects and ulcers.

 

Cobalt blue- Tryptan blue - Corneal ulcer (Option A):

  • Cobalt blue is a filter that is commonly used in conjunction with fluorescein stain, as it enhances the fluorescence of fluorescein, making it easier to detect corneal defects. It absorbs light in the blue spectrum (around 490 nm) and helps the fluorescein stain emit a bright yellow-green fluorescence when illuminated. Tryptan blue is not the preferred or standard stain for detecting corneal ulcers. While it can stain the corneal tissue, it does not provide the clear fluorescence that fluorescein does when combined with a cobalt blue filter. While cobalt blue is useful in conjunction with certain dyes, tryptan blue is not an ideal choice for assessing corneal ulcers.

 

Cobalt green- Rose bengal stain- Corneal ulcer (Option B):

Rose bengal

  • Rose bengal is a derivative of fluorescein and is used to detect ocular surface damage. It was initially theorized that rose bengal stains dead and devitalized tissue, but it is now thought to stain any part of the ocular surface which is not protected by an overlying tear film, specifically in areas lacking membrane-associated mucins.

 

Cobalt blue- Lissamine green- Corneal ulcer (Option D):

Lissamine green

  • It has a high affinity for staining dead and degenerated cells, including mucous strands. The dye appears to stain areas where there are disrupted intercellular junctions. Use of a green (red-free) filter shows the stained areas to appear black in color. As it is better tolerated than rose bengal, it is the preferred dye for staining the bulbar conjunctiva.

questions.text: The eye examination of a 20-year-old male shows a golden ring on the cornea. What of the following is the investigation of choice to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Serum ceruloplasmin

Explanation:

  • The golden ring on the cornea seen in this 20-year-old male is characteristic of Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are typically associated with Wilson's disease. Wilson’s disease is a genetic disorder of copper metabolism that leads to copper accumulation in various tissues, including the liver, brain, and cornea.
  • Kayser-Fleischer rings are copper deposits that form in the Descemet membrane of the cornea, appearing as a golden or greenish ring on slit-lamp examination.

Wilson’s disease

  • Deficiency of ceruloplasmin, leading to abnormal copper deposition in tissues.
  • Symptoms:
    • Liver disease
    • Basal ganglia dysfunction (movement disorders)
    • Psychiatric disturbances
  • Ocular Signs:
    • Kayser-Fleischer ring: Brownish-yellow golden copper deposits in the corneal Descemet membrane, visible on gonioscopy.
    • Sunflower cataract: Anterior capsular cataract in some patients.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Kayser-Fleischer rings detected on gonioscopy.
    • Serum Ceruloplasmin levels
  • Treatment: Penicillamine therapy can reduce copper deposits and improve symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Alpha-1-antitrypsin (Option A): This is a protein associated with lung and liver diseases (like emphysema and cirrhosis), but it is not related to copper metabolism or Wilson's disease.

Alpha-fetoprotein (Option B): This is a tumor marker, often elevated in certain cancers or during pregnancy, but not associated with Wilson’s disease or corneal findings.

Serum iron (Option C): Elevated iron levels are associated with hemochromatosis or iron overload disorders, not with Wilson’s disease.

questions.text: A child with elevated liver enzymes presented to the OPD with the following eye finding on gonioscopy. It is associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Copper

  • Wilson Disease is characterized by abnormal copper deposition in tissues, caused by a deficiency of caeruloplasmin.
  • Eye Finding: The child has a Kayser-Fleischer ring, a brownish-yellow copper deposit in the Descemet membrane of the cornea, which is visible on gonioscopy. This is a hallmark sign of Wilson disease.

Wilson’s disease

  • Deficiency of caeruloplasmin, leading to abnormal copper deposition in tissues.
  • Symptoms:
    • Liver disease
    • Basal ganglia dysfunction (movement disorders)
    • Psychiatric disturbances
  • Ocular Signs:
    • Kayser-Fleischer ring: Brownish-yellow copper deposits in the corneal Descemet membrane, visible on gonioscopy.
    • Sunflower cataract: Anterior capsular cataract in some patients.
  • Diagnosis: Kayser-Fleischer rings detected on gonioscopy.
  • Treatment: Penicillamine therapy can reduce copper deposits and improve symptoms.

Zinc (Option B), selenium (Option C), and iron (Option D) are not associated with the Kayser-Fleischer ring or the specific symptoms of Wilson disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the corneal epithelium?

choices.text: Regeneration is limited to the limbus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Bowman’s membrane regenerates

Layers of Cornea

Epithelium

 
  • The outermost layer comprises 5-6 layers of non-keratinized, stratified squamous epithelial cells.(Option C ruled out)
  • Acts as a barrier, protecting the cornea and preventing tear fluid from entering the underlying stroma.
  • Outermost layer Apical cells have microvilli to move the tear fluid.(Option D ruled out)
  • The basal cells at the limbus are stem cells responsible for regenerating the corneal epithelium.

Bowman’s Membrane

 
  • Located just beneath the epithelium, this acellular layer is 12 µm thick and composed of densely packed collagen fibrils.
  • It is a protective barrier to the stroma but cannot regenerate (Option B) if damaged and heals by scarring.

Stroma
  • Making up about 90% of the cornea's thickness (approximately 0.5 mm thick), the stroma consists of collagen fibrils arranged in parallel layers.
  • These fibrils are embedded in a hydrated matrix of proteoglycans - Chondroitin and Keratan Sulphate (keratan sulphate maintains corneal transparency).

Pre-Descemet's Membrane (Dua's Layer)
  • This layer, discovered in 2013, is about 15 µm thick, acellular, and lies just above Descemet's membrane.
  • It is strong and resistant to air penetration.

Descemet's Membrane
  • A robust basement membrane of the corneal endothelium is made of collagen and glycoproteins.
  • It is tense, but when torn, curls inwards on itself.
  • It can regenerate (Option A ruled out) if damaged and is resistant to trauma and pathological processes.

Endothelium

 
  • The innermost layer consists of a single layer of flat, hexagonal cells.
  • These cells are crucial for maintaining corneal transparency by regulating fluid balance within the cornea through an active pump mechanism.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 23-year-old male who has been experiencing eye pain, sensitivity to light, and redness for the last two days, following an injury caused by brushing his eyes against leaves and thorns while gardening?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fungal keratitis

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of pain, redness in eyes following trauma with vegetative matter is suggestive of Fungal Keratitis.

Fungal Keratitis:

Etiology
  • Causative organism: Aspergillus fumigatus >> Fusarium
  • Predisposing factor: Vegetative matter injury (trauma) (Option C)

Clinical Features
  • SIGNS >> symptoms
  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering/ Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision, Redness

Examination Findings
  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry, elevated, rolled-out margins
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish, dematiaceous fungi
  • Feathery Extensions: Finger-like projections in stroma
  • Sterile Immune Ring: Yellow line of demarcation
  • Satellite Lesions: Small lesions around the main ulcer
  • Hypopyon: Large, immobile, non-sterile, even in small ulcer
  • Perforation: Rare but possible

Investigations
  • Corneal Scraping: For microbiological examination
  • Wet KOH Mount: Filamentous fungi or yeast-like fungi (Candida)
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar for fungal culture
  • PCR: For rapid identification of pathogens
  • Corneal Biopsy: For deep stromal abscess or negative cultures

Treatment
  • Topical Antifungal Agents: Natamycin 5%, Voriconazole, Amphotericin-B, Nystatin
  • Oral Antifungal Agents: Ketoconazole, Voriconazole (for severe ulcers)
  • Surgical Management:
    • Repeated Scraping: Removal of necrotic material
    • Cauterization Options: Carbolic acid (100%), Trichloroacetic acid (10%–20%), Povidone-iodine (5%)
    • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Corneal transplantation

Bacterial and Fungal Keratitis:

 

BACTERIAL KERATITIS (Option B)

FUNGAL KERATITIS

Etiology
  • S. aureus (worldwide)
  • S. epidermidis (India)
  • Aspergillus

Examination Findings
  • Fluorescein stain positive ulcer
  • Hypopyon (sterile)
  • Stromal edema
  • Descemet’s membrane folds
  • Keratic precipitates due to anterior uveitis
  • Signs >>> symptoms
  • Dry/rough ulcer
  • Has projecting ends
  • Thick immobile unsterile hypopyon
  • Satellite nodules are infective and have immune reaction- Wessley ring
  • IOP is high

Treatment
  • Empirical monotherapy: Moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin, besifloxacin
  • Duo therapy: Gram positive + gram negative. Combination of Cefazolin with Gentamicin or Cefuroxime with Gentamicin.
  • Cycloplegics and mydriatics
  • Antifungals: Natamycin 5%, amphotericin B
  • Steroids are contraindicated

Simplex Keratitis (Option A): Caused due to infection by Herpes simplex virus (HSV-1). Unlike Fungal keratitis, Simplex keratitis is acquired by kissing or in close contact with an infected person. Dendritic ulcer with budding pattern is suggestive of Simplex keratitis.

Acanthameoba keratitis (option D): Usually seen in contact lens users, pseudodendritic pattern with tapering ends is suggestive of Acanathamoeba Keratitis.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options does not exhibit a characteristic of keratoconus?
questions.solution:
Haab's striae are horizontal breaks or scars in Descemet's membrane and are typically associated with congenital glaucoma (especially buphthalmos) rather than keratoconus. These striae occur as a result of increased intraocular pressure and are not a feature of keratoconus.

Keratoconus

  • Definition: Progressive, non-inflammatory bilateral ectatic corneal condition affecting the axial part.
  • Pathology: Involves progressive thinning and ectasia of the cornea due to defective synthesis of mucopolysaccharides and collagen.

Clinical Features

  • Symptoms:
    • Defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism, uncorrectable by glasses.
    • Blurred and distorted vision, glare, halos around lights.
    • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation.
    • Visual loss mainly from irregular astigmatism and myopia; secondary loss due to corneal scarring.

Examination Findings

  • Corneal Thinning & Bulging: The Cornea thins near the centre and bulges forward, with the cone apex slightly below the corneal centre.
  • Specific Signs:
    • Distorted Window Reflex: Visual irregularity on corneal reflection.
    • Placido Disc Irregularity: Circles appear irregular.
    • Slit-Lamp Examination:
      • Thinning and ectasia of the central cornea.
      • Opacity at the apex, Fleischer Ring: Brownish ring around the cone, possibly due to haemosiderin in the epithelium.
      • Folds in Descemet's and Bowman's membranes.
      • Vogt Striae: Fine, parallel striae at the apex, best seen with a slit lamp, disappearing with external pressure (vs Haab striae: They are curvilinear breaks in Descemet's membrane, resulting acutely from stretching of the cornea in primary congenital glaucoma).

Oil droplet reflex

  • Retinoscopy: Yawning reflex (scissor reflex) with high oblique/irregular astigmatism. (Option D ruled out)
  • Distant Direct Ophthalmoscopy: Annular dark shadow (oil droplet reflex) separating central and peripheral cornea. A ring of shadow concentric with the margin in the red reflex, resembling an oil droplet.
  • Ophthalmoscope Findings: Irregular Astigmatism: Progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism in later stages, poorly corrected by glasses. (Option C ruled out)
  • Munson's Sign: Localized bulging of the lower lid when looking down (seen in late stages). (Option B ruled out)
  • Keratometer Findings: Malformed, malaligned, and malfocused mires.
  • Corneal Topography: The most sensitive method for early detection (Forme Fruste Keratoconus) shows the shape of the corneal surface.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with pain and redness in the right eye following an injury during welding. On examination, the image as seen below is observed. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Removal by 26G needle

  • In managing a patient with pain and redness in the right eye following a welding injury, the most appropriate next step is removal by a 26G needle. This approach is typically indicated when there is a foreign body present in the eye, which is common in welding injuries due to flying debris.
  • This method is effective for extracting superficial foreign bodies from the cornea. It allows for direct access to remove small metallic fragments or other debris that can cause significant irritation and potential damage to the eye.

Steroids and antibiotics (Option A): While these medications can be useful for treating inflammation and preventing infection, they are not the first-line treatment for immediate foreign body removal.

Surgical exploration (Option B): This option may be considered for more complex injuries or if there are complications, but it is not the first step in straightforward foreign body cases.

Keratoplasty (Option C): This surgical procedure is reserved for severe corneal damage or scarring and is not appropriate immediately after an injury

questions.text: What dye and filter are used in the image, as shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fluorescein dye cobalt blue filter

Explanation:

Fluorescein sodium

  • Fluorescein penetrates poorly into the lipid layer of the corneal epithelium, and therefore, it does not stain normal cornea. Although fluorescein is a very effective stain for the diseased cornea, it is more difficult to detect fluorescein staining of the conjunctiva because of the poor scleral contrast. Fluorescein absorbs light in the blue spectrum (490 nm) and emits yellow-green light of a higher wavelength (530 nm), therefore staining can be more readily viewed if a cobalt blue or yellow (blue-free) filter is used. This combination is particularly useful for detecting corneal defects and ulcers.

Cobalt blue filter:

  • Cobalt blue is a filter that is commonly used in conjunction with fluorescein stain, as it enhances the fluorescence of fluorescein, making it easier to detect corneal defects. It absorbs light in the blue spectrum (around 490 nm) and helps the fluorescein stain emit a bright yellow-green fluorescence when illuminated.

Lissamine green dye

  • It has a high affinity for staining dead and degenerated cells, including mucous strands. The dye appears to stain areas where there are disrupted intercellular junctions. Use of a green (red-free) filter shows the stained areas to appear black in color. As it is better tolerated than rose bengal, it is the preferred dye for staining the bulbar conjunctiva.

Incorrect Options:

Lissamine green dye green filter (Option A):

  • Lissamine green stains dead or degenerated cells and mucous strands on the conjunctiva, not corneal defects.
  • A green filter is used with lissamine green because it enhances contrast, making stained areas appear black. It’s not effective for fluorescein.

Lissamine green dye cobalt blue filter (Option B):

  • Lissamine green doesn’t fluoresce, so a cobalt blue filter (which works with fluorescein) won’t enhance its staining.
  • Cobalt blue is useful for fluorescein fluorescence, not for lissamine green, which requires a green filter.

Fluorescein dye green filter (Option C):

  • Fluorescein works best with a cobalt blue filter for fluorescence, not a green filter. A green filter doesn’t enhance fluorescein’s fluorescence, making it less effective for detecting corneal defects.

questions.text: Keratometer is used to assess
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Curvature of cornea:

  • A keratometer is an ophthalmic instrument used to measure the curvature of the cornea.. It is primarily used to assess the central corneal curvature and determine the refractive power of the cornea.
  • The keratometer is based on the fact that the anterior surface of the cornea acts as a convex mirror, so the size of the image produced varies with its curvature.
  • Therefore, from the size of the image formed by the anterior surface of the cornea (first Purkinje image), the radius of curvature of the cornea can be calculated.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Fleischer’s ring is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Keratoconus:

  • Fleischer's ring is a characteristic finding observed in keratoconus.
  • Fleischer's ring appears as a dark, iron-colored ring around the base of the cone-shaped cornea when seen under cobalt blue filter. It is caused by the deposition of iron within the cornea due to mechanical stress and changes in the corneal structure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. FLeischer’s ring is not associated with these conditions.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with recurrent fluctuations in his vision prescription. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Keratoconus: 

  • Keratoconus is a progressive eye condition characterized by thinning and bulging of the cornea, resulting in a cone-shaped corneal surface. This abnormal corneal shape can cause frequent changes in the refractive error of the eye in young adults leading to the repeated changes in glasses prescription.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pathological myopia: Pathological myopia refers to severe nearsightedness caused due to overstretching of retina, excessive axial length, overstretching of the eyeball, it will not lead to frequent changes of glass.

Option C - Glaucoma: Glaucoma is a condition that damages the optic nerve, often due to increased pressure within the eye presenting with headache, and visual field defect.

Option D - Cataract: Cataract refers to the clouding of the eye's natural lens, leading to blurry vision, it will not lead to frequent changes of glass..

questions.text: Please analyze the image provided and determine the specific abnormality or injury present.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Viral keratitis:

  • The lesion in viral keratitis is typically characterized by dendritic or branching patterns on the cornea, as seen in the image.
  • Viral keratitis is a type of corneal infection caused by a virus, such as herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV). 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fungal keratitis: The lesion in fungal keratitis often presents as an infiltrate or ulcer with feathery edges (hyphae) and satellite lesions.

Option C - Bacterial keratitis: The lesion in bacterial keratitis often presents with ulcer, stromal edema, inflammation, and keratic precipitates due to anterior uveitis.

Option D - Interstitial keratitis: This is a condition in which there is inflammation of the cornea that affects the middle layer (stroma) of the cornea. The lesion in interstitial keratitis is typically characterized by a hazy appearance of the cornea, with no obvious ulcer or infiltrate.

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Viral keratitis:

  • Viral keratitis is a condition characterized by inflammation of the cornea caused by a viral infection. One of the classic manifestations of viral keratitis is the presence of a dendritic ulcer, which is a branching pattern of corneal epithelial lesions resembling a tree branch or dendrite. These ulcers are typically caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV) and are commonly seen in cases of herpetic keratitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bacterial keratitis: It typically presents with a more localized and suppurative (pus-forming) corneal ulcer along with a sterile hypopyon in the anterior chamber.

Option B - Fungal keratitis: It is characterized by dry/rough white ulcer with feathery ends, satellite nodules around it and a non sterile hypopyon.

Option D - Syphilitic keratitis: It typically presents as an interstitial keratitis and absent light reflex with positive accommodation reflex in neurosyphilis.

questions.text: Which drug is contraindicated in infectious keratitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Steroids:  

  • Steroids are contraindicated in the treatment of infectious keratitis. Infectious keratitis is usually caused by bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites, and it is essential to avoid using steroids as they can exacerbate the infection and potentially lead to severe complications.
  • Steroids have immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory properties, which can suppress the body's immune response to the infection. This suppression can hinder the ability to fight off the invading microorganisms, leading to prolonged infection, increased tissue damage, and potentially worsening vision loss.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Teardrops: Tear drops, or artificial tears, are often used to provide lubrication and relieve dryness or discomfort in the eyes due to non-healing ulcer

Option C - Cycloplegics: Cycloplegic eye drops are used to temporarily paralyze the muscles of the eye, primarily to dilate the pupil and relieve pain associated with spasm, prevents posterior synechiae formation, and increase blood supply..

Option D - Timolol: Timolol is a medication commonly used to lower intraocular pressure in conditions such as glaucoma. It is used in keratitis with impending perforation.

questions.text: What is the origin of corneal endothelium?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neural crest cells:

  • The corneal endothelium is derived from neural crest cells during embryonic development. It plays a crucial role in maintaining corneal transparency by regulating the fluid balance in the cornea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Neuroectoderm: Secondary vitreous, tertiary vitreous, optic nerve, retina, smooth muscles of the iris (iris sphincter and dilator pupillae), and epithelium lining of iris and ciliary body are derived from neuroectoderm.

Option C - Mesoderm: Primary vitreous, temporal part of sclera, extra ocular parts, and endothelial lining of the blood vessels are derived from mesoderm.

Option D - Surface ectoderm: The skin of eyelids and appendages, lens, lacrimal gland, epithelium of the cornea, and epithelium of conjunctiva are derived from surface ectoderm.

questions.text:
Assertion: Topical steroids should not be used in the treatment of viral corneal ulcers.

Reason: Topical steroids can cause increased intraocular pressure

What is the correct option?

choices.text: Both assertion and reasoning are correct and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reasoning are independently correct and reason is not correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is independently a correct statement, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Both assertion and reasoning are independently correct and reason is not correct explanation of the assertion:

  • Both assertion and reasoning are independently correct, but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion: The assertion that topical steroids are contraindicated in viral corneal ulcers is true. This is because topical steroids in such cases can hinder the body's immune response to the infection and results in perforated corneal ulcer..
  • The reasoning stating that topical steroids can cause increased intraocular pressure is also true but does not directly explain the contraindication in viral corneal ulcers.

Incorrect Option:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Atropine Sulfate eye ointment:

  • Atropine Sulfate eye ointment is the adjuvant therapy commonly used in fungal corneal ulcers.
    • To reduce pain from ciliary spasms.
    • To prevent the formation of posterior synechiae.
    • It increases the blood supply to the anterior uvea by relieving pressure on the anterior ciliary arteries and brings more antibodies into the aqueous humor.
    • It also reduces exudation by decreasing hyperemia and vascular permeability.

Incorrect Option:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. These are not used as the adjunctive therapy for fungal keratitis.

questions.text: A 30 year old man presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. Upon examination, corneal ulcer with feathery ends and satellite lesions around it are seen. What would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fungal corneal ulcer:

  • The most likely pathology in this case is a fungal corneal ulcer. The history of an eye injury caused by a leaf, along with symptoms of pain, photophobia, redness, and examination revealing corneal ulcer with feathery edges (hyphae) surrounded by satellite lesions are suggestive of fungal keratitis..

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior uveitis: It typically presents with pain, redness, photophobia , and blurred vision, keratic precipitates, and aqueous flare.

Option B - Conjunctivitis: It is characterized by redness, pain, photophobia, discharge depending on the infecting organism, follicles or papillae in the palpebral conjunctiva.
