Option D - HSV corneal ulcer: Ulcer caused by herpes simplex virus usually presents with superficial punctate keratitis and dendritic ulcer which may progress to geographical ulcer.

questions.text: What is the likely reason for a 21-year-old student to have ocular redness, feeling of a foreign object in the eye, and excessive tearing after wearing a soft contact lens, as indicated by the corneal scraping interface contrast microscopy image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acanthamoeba:

  • The clinical presentation of ocular redness, foreign body sensation, epiphora, history of using a soft contact lens, and image showing a cyst of acanthamoeba characterized by outer wrinkled wall is suggestive of acanthamoeba keratitis caused by acanthamoeba a free living protozoan.
  • It is prevalent in individuals using soft contact lens and using tap water for cleaning or swimming with the contact lens in a swimming pool.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Naegleria fowleri: Naegleria fowleri is a free-living amoeba that can cause a rare and often fatal brain infection known as primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).

Option C - Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is a parasitic amoeba that can cause amoebiasis, a gastrointestinal infection.

Option D - Balamuthia mandrillaris: Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living amoeba that can cause a rare and often fatal brain infection known as granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE).

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 27-year-old male patient who experiences eye trauma from vegetative matter, and currently exhibits symptoms including a corneal ulcer, hypopyon, satellite lesions, mild pain, photophobia, and redness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fungal keratitis:

  • The history of trauma with vegetative matter and the clinical features of a corneal ulcer, hypopyon, and satellite lesions are highly suggestive of fungal keratitis.
  • Fungal keratitis is a serious ocular infection that can result from trauma with vegetative matter, such as plant material, which can introduce fungal spores into the eye. 
  • The symptoms of fungal keratitis include pain, photophobia, redness, and a corneal ulcer with a feathery or irregular border. 
  • Hypopyon (pus in the anterior chamber of the eye) and satellite lesions (smaller ulcers around the main ulcer) are also common in fungal keratitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Acanthamoeba keratitis: Acanthamoeba keratitis is a rare but serious eye infection caused by a free-living amoeba. It is typically associated with contact lens wear using tap water to clean and can present as painful, red eye with photophobia, blurred vision and ring like lesion n cornea. However, the presence of hypopyon and satellite lesions is not typical of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Option C - Viral keratitis: Viral keratitis is an infection of the cornea caused by a virus, such as herpes simplex virus. It can cause a painful, red eye with photophobia, stellate lesion, dendritic ulcer or geographical ulcer.

Option D - Bacterial keratitis: Bacterial keratitis is characterized by a dry/rough ulcer, with hypopyon (pus cells), stromal edema, descemet's membrane fold, and keratic precipitates due to anterior uveitis.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Keratoconus:

  • The given image is of V-shaped deformity on looking down is characteristic od keratoconus.
  • Keratoconus is a progressive eye disorder characterized by thinning and bulging of the cornea, which results in a cone-shaped deformity.
  • This condition can cause visual distortion, blurry vision, and astigmatism.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior uveitis: Anterior uveitis is inflammation of the front portion of the uvea, which includes the iris and ciliary body. It is characterized by aqueous cells, flare, keratic precipitates, and photophobia.

Option B - Glaucoma: Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions characterized by damage to the optic nerve, often caused by increased intraocular pressure.

Option C - Optic neuritis: Optic neuritis refers to inflammation of the optic nerve, which can cause vision loss, reduced visual activity, RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect), dyschromatopsia, decreased contrast sensitivity, nerve fiber bundle defect, and visual field
